'''''Protostropharia semiglobata''''', commonly known as the '''dung roundhead''', the '''halfglobe mushroom''', or the '''hemispheric stropharia''', is an [[agaric]] fungus of the family [[Strophariaceae]]. A common and widespread species with a [[cosmopolitan distribution]], the fungus produces [[mushroom]]s on the [[Feces|dung]] of various wild and domesticated [[herbivore]]s. The mushrooms have hemispherical straw yellow to [[buff (color)|buff]]-[[tan (color)|tan]] [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] measuring {{convert|1|–|4|cm|in|1|abbr=on}}, greyish [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] that become dark brown in age, and a slender, smooth [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] {{convert|3|–|12|cm|in|abbr=on}} long with a fragile [[annulus (mycology)|ring]].

==Taxonomy==
The species was first described as ''Agaricus semiglobatus'' by [[August Batsch]] in 1786.<ref name="Batsch 1786"/> It has had a complicated [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] history, having been shuffled to many different genera. In addition to ''Agaricus'' the species has been placed in ''[[Coprinus]]'', ''[[Geophila]]'', ''[[Psalliota]]'', and ''[[Psilocybe]]''.  French mycologist [[Lucien Quélet]] gave it its most commonly used name in 1872 when he transferred it to ''[[Stropharia]]''.<ref name="Quélet 1872"/> In 2013, Scott Redhead made it the [[type species]] of ''[[Protostropharia]]'', a new genus circumscribed to contain  ''Stropharia'' species characterized by the formation of astrocystidia rather than [[acanthocyte (mycology)|acanthocytes]] on their [[mycelium]].<ref name="Redhead 2013a"/> A [[form (botany)|form]] ''sterilis'' and two [[variety (botany)|varieties]], ''minor'' and ''radicata'', described by F.H. Møller in 1945,<ref name="Møller 1945"/> are no longer considered to have independent taxonomic significance.<ref name="urlMycoBank: Stropharia semiglobata"/>

The [[botanical name|specific epithet]] ''semiglobata'' is [[Latin]] for "half-spherical", and refers to the shape of the cap.<ref name="Evenson 1997"/> It is [[common name|commonly]] known as the halfglobe mushroom, the hemispheric stropharia,<ref name="Ammirati 1985"/> the round stropharia,<ref name="Bessette1997"/> or the dung roundhead.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/>

==Description==
[[File:Stropharia semiglobata 38288.jpg|thumb|left|The gills of this young specimen are still grayish.]]
The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is obtuse to hemispherical in shape, reaching a diameter of {{convert|1|–|4|cm|in|1|abbr=on}}. The cap surface is smooth and sticky, and initially has a light yellow color that fades in maturity to dull yellow or whitish. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] have an adnate attachment to the stem with a slight decurrent tooth. They are distantly spaced and broad–about 6–8 mm; mature gills become ventricose (swollen). The gills are initially grayish, but become purplish brown to dark purple as the spores mature. The edges of the gills are white and fringed. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is {{convert|3|–|12|cm|in|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|0.2|–|0.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick, with a bulbous base. Initially filled with a cottony pith, the stem becomes hollow in maturity. A delicate [[annulus (mycology)|ring]] forms an annular zone on the mid to upper portion of the stem that may be darkened from spore deposits. Above the annular zone, the stem is covered with fine silk-like hairs; below, it is sticky. The stem tissue is white with a yellowish pith.<ref name="Ammirati 1985"/> The flesh has no distinctive odor, and a taste that is mild to slightly bitter.<ref name="Laursen 2009"/> The fruit bodies have been listed as [[edible mushroom|edible]] by some authors, but [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]] by others;<ref name="Roberts 2011"/>  even when not toxic, mushrooms that grow on dung are usually considered unpalatable,<ref name="Miller 2006"/> though the [[Agaricus bisporus|common mushroom]] is an obvious counter-example.

The mushroom produce a dark purple [[spore print]]. The thick-walled [[spore]]s are ellipsoidal, smooth, and have a small apical [[germ pore]]; they measure 16.1–19.0 by 8.8–11.0 [[micrometre|μm]]. The [[basidia]] (spore-bearing cells) are four-spored, club-shaped, [[hyaline]] (translucent), and measure 33–40 by 13–14.6 μm.<ref name="Ammirati 1985"/>

===Similar species===
Other mushrooms that resemble ''Protostropharia semiglobosa'' include ''[[Stropharia dorsispora]]'', ''[[Stropharia luteonitens|S. luteonitens]]'', and ''[[Panaeolus semiovatus]]''.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/>

==Habitat and distribution==
A [[saprobic]] species, the fungus fruits in small groups on dung, in soil containing manure, on lawns, grasslands, or in livestock corrals.<ref name="Ammirati 1985"/> It has been recorded on the dung of a variety of wild and domesticated [[herbivore]]s and [[ungulate]]s, including rabbit, sheep, cow, buffalo, moose, bear, and wallaby.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/><ref name="Laursen 2009"/><ref name="Miller 2006"/> In some instances, the dung substrate is under [[moss]] so that it appears as if the mushroom is growing from the moss.<ref name="Laursen 2009"/> Fruits bodies sometimes occur with another dung-loving fungus, ''[[Deconica coprophila]]''.<ref name="Roody 2003"/> A widespread and common species, ''P. semiglobosa'' has a [[cosmopolitan distribution]],<ref name="Noordeloos 1999"/> having been recorded from northern Asia, Australia, Europe, Central and South America, North America, North Africa, and New Zealand.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/>  It is thought to have been [[introduced species|introduced]] to Australia with imported domestic stock.<ref name="Smith 2005"/>
